post_info.post_title: the home enviroment is vital for characther building

sinjin

is the home enviroment vital for characther building? why?

 
 Assuming you live with people of character.
jim's trucking

I believe each of us is a product of our environment.
 
 Several years ago I had a weekly continual dinner conversation over a span of about two years with a friend regarding a hypothetical experiment wherein a child is born into a life support box that provides food, air, water, light, waste disposal and a survivable climate. We would spend hours after dinner, toasting our own health and well being and discussing what we thought the child would learn on its own throughout several years of confinement. I concluded that the child would learn very little if anything aside from where the food and water came from...and that only the survival instinct would keep it alive.
 
 We then expanded the "experiment" to what a person might learn as it grew up alone in the world, with no other humans.
 
 Later still we expanded the scene to include two humans...then a small group...then a large group. 
 
 The exercise brought out a lot of conversation regarding parental input, peer input, historical data, language, art, music, science, inventions and other things that we learn from others and from books.
 
 It was essentially an entertainment tool for us and produced no conclusions that could be stated with any degree of confidence, but it was fun while it lasted...and we enjoyed many fine cigars together. It did reinforce our common belief that the environment in which a child develops will determine what kind of person the child turns into.
 
 Not that this relates totally to your question, but I believe the character of the child is directly related to the character values to which it is exposed in the formative years. I've noted exceptions to this in some families where the child went totally astray from the parents so I suppose no hard and fast rules apply.
 
 I do believe this thread belongs on another forum.
unkerpaulie

hmmm... jim, have you ever considered what would happen if instead of a human child, you put a newborn kitten or goat or bird in isolation, and investigate what exactly they would learn on their own. i'm sure this has been done numerous times. but just speculate, are humans so dependent on others' teaching them that they could not learn solely on instincts or self-discovery? what do other animals learn from their social environment that they wouldnt typically learn in isolation?
jim's trucking

hmmm... jim, have you ever considered what would happen if instead of a human child, you put a newborn kitten or goat or bird in isolation, and investigate what exactly they would learn on their own. i'm sure this has been done numerous times. but just speculate, are humans so dependent on others' teaching them that they could not learn solely on instincts or self-discovery? what do other animals learn from their social environment that they wouldnt typically learn in isolation?
I've not given any thought to what might happen to a cat in isolation. Besides, it would be difficult to compare what they might learn in isolation as opposed to a normal upbringing because I have no idea what they should have learned anyway.
 
 I've seen on nature shows where a momma cat (leopard) teaches the young to hunt and kill. (Polar bears, too.) I suspect that the isolated cat would continue to come to whatever food source is provided and never seek an alternate diet or means of obtaining food. Then again, a hungry dog will try to eat a brick.
 
 The stories that have been documented about orphaned geese and the use of ultra-light aircraft to teach them to fly south in the winter are amazing...but geese don't nurse...they start eating whatever's available shortly after hatching. I think the only reason young geese in the wild fly south for the first time is because all the other geese went that way.
 
 I've seen one story about saving the California Condor in which "mommy looking" hand puppets were used to "regurgitate" food to the young hatchlings. I don't remember how they developed their flying skills, but I understand several have been successfully released into the wild.
 
 I think animals have many more behaviors attributed to instinct than do we. Most of the reptiles I'm aware of are on their own when born or hatched. How does a baby rattler know that his fangs can be used to kill a rat?
 
 Alligators don't get any parental training. Neither do snakes or turtles. They just strike out on their own. Most fish receive very little parental care. Salmon certainly don't get any. I've heard of some fish whose parents will protect them by storing them in their big fat mouths, but I've never heard of any fish teaching its young what or how to eat unless those who hang around their parents learn by watching them eat other fish.
 
 Speaking of turtles, how do they know to return to the same beach to lay eggs? How do salmon find the stream of their own birth after being at sea for years?
 
 I think most all animals and insects have an instinctive drive to survive...after all, you start trying to stomp on a cockroach and he scurries for cover...you capture a cricket in your hand and he tries to get away (and often does before I get the hook in)...garden spiders will run from an approaching lawn mower...almost any healthy animal that doesn't consider you to be food or see you as a threat to their young will run when approached. Even your neighbor's dog will be wary of you until he gains confidence that you are not out to hurt him.

 I fall somewhere in the middle.

unkerpaulie

jim, its clear that many animals dont learn from social interation with other animals of its kind. however, its ENVIRONMENT is its own teacher. a baby snake will learn to hide in the shade of a rock, and by trial and error learn that you can eat a cricket but not a leaf, even though their "hopping" movements might look the same.
 
 what if we put this snake in a containment where the natural environment is missing. food and water is provided, and there is no threats or negative consequences to anything the snake does. even though the snake is capable of killing animals with a bite, all his food is pre-killed for him, and he never has to use his fangs
 
 say we release this snake into the wild as an adult. will he be oblivious to potential danger? or will he be immediately paranoid about everything in this new environment, striking out at sticks and fruits as readily as animals? besides the memory of the smell of the food he's been given all his life, i think he'd have to learn how to survive just as he would as a baby snake
 
 i think the difference between humans and animals is in how quickly they learn, rather than what knowledge they are born with. most animals have at least one sense that is much more acute than in humans. also, they develop quicker (shorter gestation periods; shorter adult life-cycles), so its common to develop much of their survival skills within their first day of life. many animals that need a social structure to survive usually have a long maturity cycle, but thats not always the case

 what if we put this snake in a containment where the natural environment is missing. food and water is provided, and there is no threats or negative consequences to anything the snake does. even though the snake is capable of killing animals with a bite, all his food is pre-killed for him, and he never has to use his fangs

...and I think snakes have barely a brain when compared to cats, dogs, horses, pigs, elephants, chimps, etc. Snakes likely have less brain power than most any four legged animal. I think everything a snake does is by instinct or the fact that he can't stand the heat of the day. For instance, I don't think that a side winder was taught to hold all but two points on his body off the hot sand. I think it just "said" to itself, "damn that's hot, I think I'll lift off of it"....same thing with that silly desert lizard that stands on two feet, right front and left rear, until his little feet get too hot, then he swaps on both ends for a while. Nobody taught him to do that.. It was pain. He instrinctively lifts his feet to relieve the pain just as a human instinctively pulls away from a fire when it gets too hot to bear.
 
 (JMO, of course...please don't ask for backup links.)
 
 
 

 i think the difference between humans and animals is in how quickly they learn, rather than what knowledge they are born with. most animals have at least one sense that is much more acute than in humans. also, they develop quicker (shorter gestation periods; shorter adult life-cycles), so its common to develop much of their survival skills within their first day of life. many animals that need a social structure to survive usually have a long maturity cycle, but thats not always the case
I think humans are animals that reason with great mental power. How else could our DNA be so close to that of the chimpanzee?

 it is related, topomite. the home environment is where humans learn the fundamental skills of coping with the outside world. the extent of nuturing young children get varies from home to home. in the animal kindom, some animals experience simialar parental nuturing, and some dont. what we are discussing is how much basic survival skills can a human child learn on his own, in comparison to other animals. its also about what skills are the most fundamental, that even if there was nobody to teach us, we'd eventually (or instinctively) learn to do on our own
 
 do animals "figure out" how to use their special abilities by trial and error? how much of their activity is involuntary reflex (totally built-in mechanism)? what do they or can they learn by mimicking other animals of their species?
 
 similarly in humans, could we learn to survive outside of a social structure and others to mimic? do we have enough survival instinct built-in? or are we totally helpless without a family to nuture us as children?
 
 its not as off-topic as you think

people, we are talking about the home environment here, not the wilderness. and it is about character building.
The "home environment" includes things outside of the house.
 
 I've stated that I think we are all products of our own environments. Since most of us are raised in some sort of home environment, it follows that home environment is a major player in molding a person's character and degree of learning.
 
 Whether someone is reared in a traditional "mommy, daddy, siblings" home, or a foster home, or a boys home, or a monestary, or in whatever kind of home you can imagine (including the wilderness)...the character (good or bad) of the person's home-leaders (if any) will be present in the person.
 
 
 
 This is, of course, just my opinion. I welcome rebuttal and concurrence.
